executive_summary: The industry comprises two segments: larger couriers and smaller local delivery companies. Together, these segments cater to various consumers, with demand for each segment differing based on the services offered. Specifically, downstream demand for courier services comes from manufacturers and retailers across the country, while demand for local delivery services is derived from households and other local markets.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Post-Pandemic Stabilizing Economic Conditions Have Boosted Revenue Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consumer spending has trended upward in response to an increase in per capita disposable income and a decrease in unemployment in the last few years. Corporate profit has surged in the years following the pandemic, boosting demand for business-to-business shipments. Although the world price of crude oil sharply increased in 2022 after Russia invaded Ukraine, it has since declined, decreasing operation costs for this industry. A recent oil production halt in Saudi Arabia have the potential to harm industry operations through the end of 2023. While oil prices have steadily declined after 2021, this move may cause them to spike again.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: HEALTHCARE CUSTOMERS CONTINUE TO DRIVE DEMAND
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Many courier companies have made a push to serve the healthcare industry as it expands and is largely resistant to general economic conditions. More specifically, both large and small companies have made a push to serve the healthcare market. Many healthcare products including pharmaceutical companies are required to maintain a specific temperature range to maintain integrity. Therefore, couriers tailoring services to the healthcare industry must ensure that vehicles are equipped with the proper temperature control vehicles, and the delivery workers are well trained. In September of 2023, UPS announced its acquisition of MNX Global Logistics (MNX). This greatly expands UPS's capabilities both domestically and internationally. This acquisition is expected to further squeeze competition in the US in the healthcare courier industry since UPS already takes up a large portion of activity.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Competition and Environmental Regulation Will Tighten
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Competition from substitutes including the US Postal Service and Amazon.com, will negatively affect industry performance in the coming years. Amazon is able to provide most goods for consumer and deliver them next day, giving a clear advantage over industry operators, as this service is usually free with a monthly subscription.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Pandemic Induced a Surge in Carrier-Facilitated Shopping
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Package and parcel carriers, such as UPS and FedEx, are expected to benefit the most from the rise in e-commerce sales. While the US gradually moved away from pandemic restrictions during the previous period, but consumers likeness to online shopping has remained.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Smaller Couriers Will Consolidate to Experience Economies of Scale
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Enterprise growth will be driven by an increasing presence of smaller nonemployers in the industry. Smaller couriers attempting to serve niche areas, including medical device delivery or blood transportation, will continue to boost the number of industry establishments and enterprises.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Same-Day Delivery and Online Grocery Spending Will Create Higher-Value-Added Services For Couriers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Increases in demand from retail, wholesale and healthcare sectors will support industry profit over the coming years. Growth in consumer spending and the number of US businesses will generate additional demand for delivery services. Grocery spending online will dramatically increase as well, causing a surge in delivery workers needed.

industry_definition: This report combines two segments: couriers and local delivery services. Operators in the couriers segment primarily engage in delivery services between urban centers using a network of air and surface transportation systems. Conversely, operators in the local delivery services segment provide delivery services within a single urban area and are excluded from courier networks.
key_trends: Post-pandemic economic growth has boosted revenue growth.
Consumer spending and per capita disposable income have increased while unemployment has also declined.
Overall e-commerce activity was boosted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Package delivery is a reliable source of revenue as it does not have internet-based alternatives.

Demand for shipping services increases during holidays, proving to be more cyclical than anything. Thus retailers and e-commerce businesses endure a surge in orders for gifts and other items during these periods.
The EPA enforces rules that reduce diesel fuel emissions. Compliance with such regulations has increased operational costs of some companies.
Consumer preferences have shifted in favor of more efficient ground transport. As a result, ground delivery services account for the biggest chunk of revenue.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment includes retail trade, e-commerce and household delivery services like restaurant delivery.
This segment includes sectors like finance, insurance, government, manufacturers that use the industry for transactions.
This segment relates to logistics and supply chain management consultancy services.

products_and_services.product_description: Ground transportation of packages and freight.
Air transportation of packages and freight.

tier_1_suppliers: Aircraft Maintenance, Repair & Overhaul in the US
Bicycle Dealership and Repair in the US
Boat Dealership and Repair in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Freight Packing & Logistics Services in the US
Oil Change Services in the US
Public Storage & Warehousing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The growing popularity of e-commerce and same-day deliveries is driving demand in the business-to-consumer segment.
Consumers are shifting towards more efficient and cost-effective ground transport services over air and express services.
Food delivery services were uniquely positioned to meet the surge in demand during stay-at-home orders.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region has a lower percentage of establishments compared to its population percentage.
The Mid-Atlantic region has a higher percentage of establishments compared to its population percentage, indicating it generates significant business volumes for the industry.
The New England region has a lower percentage of establishments compared to its population percentage.
The Plains region has a lower percentage of establishments compared to its population percentage.
The Rocky Mountains region has a lower percentage of establishments compared to its population percentage.

The Southeast region has a higher percentage of establishments compared to its population percentage, indicating it generates significant business volumes for the industry. It is home to UPS and FedEx.
The Southwest region has a higher percentage of establishments compared to its population percentage, indicating it generates significant business volumes for the industry.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Many regions have licensing requirements. For instance, Boston requires an annual license application for commercial bicycle messenger service providers. Under Chapter 302 of the Acts of 1998 of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, providers must, pay an annual registration fee of $25.00, plus provide proof that the service and each commercial bicycle messenger used or employed has insurance coverage.

regulations_points.regulation_title: FEDERAL MOTOR CARRIER SAFETY ADMINISTRATION (FMCSA) REGULATIONS
regulations_points.regulation_description: Companies that operate commercial vehicles with a gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR) of 10,001 pounds or more must comply with FMCSA regulations, which include requirements for driver qualifications, vehicle maintenance and recordkeeping.
The FAA's main focus is to regulate civil aviation and promote safety. Aircraft must be registered with the FAA and pilots must pass a test administered by the FAA to obtain a license.
The agency enforces rules that reduce diesel fuel emissions from diesel engines. Compliance with such regulations has increased the cost of some new trucks.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Industry assistance level is low to steady.
Competition level is high to steady.

factors_decreased_barrier: Globalization level is low but increasing.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Larger Companies Dominated Market Share Concentration
concentration_points.concentration_description: A small number of companies hold a significant portion of the market share. Established companies in the industry often have strong brand recognition and customer loyalty, which can make it difficult for new companies to gain market share.
The industry's high barriers to entry make it difficult for new companies to enter the market and compete.

Large companies also acquire smaller ones to increase market share. Through mergers and acquisitions, large companies enjoy economies of scale that allow them to offer competitive prices and a wide range of services.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: A Large Portion of Purchases Relates to Fuel
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: As a result, costs can fluctuate dramatically on a year-over-year basis. To offset the volatility of fuel markets, some companies have fuel managers that are responsible for hedging against any fluctuations in price. These managers buy futures contracts, implement fuel surcharges or maintain distribution contracts with suppliers that keep costs fixed over a certain period of time. Local delivery services endure lower purchase costs as short distances and inexpensive modes of transportation spur fewer purchases.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Other Expenses Account for Nearly Half of Industry Revenue
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Other expenses include research and development, insurance, cleaning costs, customer claims for damaged packages and landing fees. Technology investments account for the largest portion of other expenses as companies are consistently upgrading systems to improve productivity and customer services. Companies also contend with costs associated with business operations including data processing fees and back-office support.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Labor investment in this industry is huge with manual labor being a substantial part of operations
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: This labor includes drivers, pilots and delivery personnel that work alongside and operate the machinery.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low levels of innovation limit the threat to incumbent operators from new technologies disrupting their operations
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: However, a low rate of growth in technology can also create exposure for incumbents as the trajectory of innovation in other markets could lead to unforeseen competitive disadvantages.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: This implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Revenue is Influenced by Overall Economic Health
volatility_points.volatility_description: A downturn in the economy can lead to a decrease in demand for delivery services as businesses and individuals may reduce their spending. However, the opposite happened during the downturn in 2020, as consumers and businesses needed to lockdown, courier demand grew massively. An increase in consumer spending and per capita disposable income boosts the number of households which in turn boosts online purchases. Similarly, in the corporate sector as the number of businesses increases, along with corporate profit, the volume of deliveries should rise. An increase in fuel prices can lead to an increase in operating costs for delivery companies, which may need to pass on these costs to customers in the form of higher prices.

volatility_points.volatility_title: DEMAND FOR THIS INDUSTRY INCREASES DURING HOLIDAYS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Retailers and e-commerce businesses endure a surge in orders for gifts and other items during holidays. This can lead to increased revenue for courier and delivery companies as they are responsible for getting those items to customers' doorsteps. Additionally, during the summer months, demand for these services may fall as people tend to travel more and businesses may also have less need for these services.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: GROUND DELIVERY ACCOUNTS FOR MORE THAN 60.0% OF INDUSTRY REVENUE
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many companies in this segment have multiple lines of business, including bus lines, messenger services, armored car services, food product delivery companies and specialized bank document couriers. Consumer preferences have shifted away from more expensive air and express services in favor of more efficient ground transport, leading to growth in this segment. Facing massive increases in families and individuals staying at home, food delivery services were uniquely equipped to satisfy the newfound demand for stay-at-home orders.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: DEMAND FOR AIR COURIER SERVICES HAS RISEN IN CONJUNCTION WITH GROWTH IN CONSUMER SPENDING AND E-COMMERCE SALES
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Major establishments in this industry offer domestic and international air courier services, larger companies own planes and sometimes even airports. The hub system, largely initiated by FedEx, requires all freight to be shipped to the company's central hub, where it's sorted and rerouted to its final destination instead of the point-to-point transit model. With the growth in the air courier industry, some regional hubs have formed to serve particular areas of the country. This segment is in direct competition with commercial airline companies that provide airfreight services.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Other Services Including Messengers and Local Deliveries Account for a Small Portion of Industry Revenue
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Most couriers and messengers deliver items within a limited geographic area including a city or metropolitan area. To limit overhead costs, many local companies use contract personnel that provides delivery services on hourly or commission-based compensation. This segment also uses a variety of different vehicles for delivery services, depending on the size of the items being delivered. Generally, cars, pickup trucks or vans transport larger packages, while motorbikes, mopeds or bicycles deliver products including documents or food.

FAQs.question: How has discretionary spending affected your major consumers?
FAQs.answer: An increase in discretionary income over the past five years has led to an increase in consumer spending via e-commerce platforms. Consumer spending fell overall in 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic-induced economic uncertainty. However, the rise in e-commerce spending outweighed the decline in consumer spending, in terms of demand for the industry, leading to industry growth in 2020. Consumer spending is estimated to have risen in 2021 and is anticipated to continue to rise in 2022 benefiting industry operators.

FAQs.question: How does your company handle changes in industrial, trade and retail activity?
FAQs.answer: The industry's revenue and sales growth acts as a barometer of overall economic activity. Retail activity largely shifted toward e-commerce offerings benefiting industry operators in 2022.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile crude oil prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: A decrease in crude oil prices has helped operators decrease fuel costs over the past five years. Moreover, the crash in oil prices in 2020 helped industry operators further decrease fuel prices. Rising oil prices in 2022 have increased operating costs for operators.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in locations with well-established infrastructure networks?
FAQs.answer: Both major players in the industry have large operations across the country helping them offer better prices on delivery and shipping. Economies of scale are widely used for larger players in the industry to cut costs and gain consumers with lower prices than competition. Consequently, the industry experiences high levels of acquisition activity.

FAQs.question: Does your company use software systems to optimize all aspects of logistics and sales channels?
FAQs.answer: Heavy technological investment in logistics technology and route optimization has helped improve profit for large operators in the industry.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Wage costs have risen in the industry over the past five years despite improvements in technology. However, over the coming five years automation is likely to rise in the form of automated warehouses and delivery vehicles, lowering wage costs.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Regulation has remained relatively steady in the industry over the past five years. Coronavirus-related health and safety regulations are estimated to have limited profit initially but are no longer a factor.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations like energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Both FedEx and UPS are increasing their fleet of energy-efficient vehicles in order to reduce their carbon footprint.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: The holiday season is critical for large operators in the industry and an increase in demand during the holiday season helps operators throughout the year. Operators additionally hire seasonal workers to help meet the surges in demand.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit for large operators has increased over the past five years on account of the shift in consumer habits toward e-commerce.

FAQs.question: How do you set yourself apart from your competitors? What value-add services could you offer?
FAQs.answer: Couriers, messengers and local deliverers provide similar services within each sector, so it is important for companies to differentiate themselves from competitors to gain market share.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain product quality? What are the associated costs?
FAQs.answer: Service providers often deliver packages and other items that are valuable or time sensitive, so it is vital for industry participants to have control systems in place that ensure deliveries are not lost or delayed. Moreover, this increased in importance during the coronavirus pandemic, especially in the 4th quarter of 2020 as e-commerce sales hit record highs.

FAQs.question: What systems do you use to track rented inventory?
FAQs.answer: <UNKNOWN>

FAQs.question: What are the costs associated with these systems?
FAQs.answer: <UNKNOWN>

FAQs.question: Ability to effectively manage debtors
FAQs.answer: Tight control of cash flow is essential in this industry, particularly within the messenger and local delivery segment, because many clients are small businesses, which typically have fewer assets and less financial stability.

FAQs.question: Does your company monitor the number of businesses?
FAQs.answer: <UNKNOWN>

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue is derived from business-to-business transactions?
FAQs.answer: <UNKNOWN>

FAQs.question: Number of businesses
FAQs.answer: Demand for delivery services depends heavily on the number of businesses in the US economy, since businesses use courier and local delivery services for business-to-business correspondence and transactions. The coronavirus temporarily led to a decline in the number of business, but this decline has been mitigated by the surge in e-commerce sales and shift of many businesses to increasingly provide e-commerce offerings.

FAQs.question: How are you affected by an increase in consumer spending? How does your company fare when consumer spending is low?
FAQs.answer: Industry revenue generally fluctuates with consumer spending, which dictates demand for goods that are transported by industry operators. The spread of coronavirus led to a temporary decrease in consumer spending; however, this decline has been mitigated by the surge in e-commerce sales resulting from shifting consumer habits and benefiting industry operators.

FAQs.question: How much of your revenue comes from e-commerce sales? Who represents your biggest clients in this segment?
FAQs.answer: <UNKNOWN>

FAQs.question: E-commerce sales
FAQs.answer: E-commerce sales represent the portion of consumer retail purchases that are made online as a proportion of total US retail sales. E-commerce sales have steadily risen over the past decade, increasing as a portion of revenue and boosting industry revenue. This upward trend was exacerbated by the coronavirus pandemic.
